docs.lead_paragraph: As my colleague John Burns reports from London, "a strong and unexpected surge by the left-of-center Liberal Democrats" ahead of the general election in Britain on May 6 has thrown the spotlight on the party's youthful leader, Nick Clegg.

headline.main: Nick Clegg Is (Not) the British Obama

docs.abstract: Much of the hyperbole is overblown, but here are five ways that Nick Clegg's run for the office of prime minister in Britain actually does seem to echo Barack Obama's campaign for the presidency in 2008.
docs.snippet: Much of the hyperbole is overblown, but here are five ways that Nick Clegg's run for the office of prime minister in Britain actually does seem to echo Barack Obama's campaign for the presidency in 2008.

headline.main: Must Self-Insured Companies Cover Adult Children?

docs.abstract: Under the new federal health law, even self-insured companies must offer coverage to employees' adult children effective Sept. 23.
docs.snippet: Under the new federal health law, even self-insured companies must offer coverage to employees' adult children effective Sept. 23.

docs.lead_paragraph: One in Three San Francisco Employees Made $100,000 | Almost one in three of 27,000 city workers in San Francisco made six-figure salaries last year, more than one in three of all city employees. It's a pay club whose membership has grown steadily over the past decade, even without counting health insurance or pension benefits. Overtime and payouts for unused vacation days sent many of those city workers' 2009 compensations over the $100,000 level. The retired deputy police chief, Charles Keohane, who left the force in mid-2009, led the pay pack, receiving $516,118 because of stored-up vacation, sick days and comp time. [The San Francisco Chronicle]

docs.lead_paragraph: International A COUP CHANGES NIGER, BUT NOT CHINA'S ROLE THERE
docs.snippet: International     A COUP CHANGES NIGER, BUT NOT CHINA'S ROLE THERE

docs.lead_paragraph: One day several years ago, I was reaching the end of my first visit with a patient, J.J., who had come to see me for anxiety and insomnia. He was a salesman for a struggling telecommunications company, and he was having trouble managing the strain on his finances and his family. He was sleeping poorly, and as soon as he opened his eyes in the early morning, the worries began. ''I wake up with a list of things to worry about,'' he said. ''I just go through the list, and it seems to get longer every day.'' A psychiatric interview has a certain rhythm to it. You start by listening to what your patient says for a few minutes, without interrupting, all the while sorting through possible diagnoses. This vast landscape of distress has been mapped into a series of categories in psychiatry's diagnostic manual, DSM-IV. The book breaks down mental suffering into 16 groups of disorders, like mood disorders, anxiety disorders, psychotic disorders, eating disorders and several others. As I listened to J.J. (a nickname that he agreed I could use to protect his privacy), it was clear to me that he had one of the anxiety disorders, but which one? In order to systematically rule in or rule out the disorders, I asked J.J. dozens of questions. ''Do you have panic attacks?'' ''Do you get fearful in crowded situations?'' ''Have you ever experienced a traumatic event that later caused flashbacks or nightmares?''
docs.abstract: Dr Daniel Carlat, Tufts University associate clinical psychiatry professor, discusses how his approach to treatment has become more psychotherapy based and less about prescribing medications; asserts that emphasis of many doctors on psychopharmacology might not serve patients or profession; notes that no other medical specialty has separate subspecialty for treatment with drugs; photo (L)
